61872440
>>61872433

61872446
>he doesnt trade his own money to become a player of the game like his clients

61872467
For someone with 200k to invest, what would you do? I’m thinking of a split between SPYI, QQQI, O, and SCHD.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61872716
interesting thread, ty anon

61872888
>>61872526
>US market has had a good run for about 15 years, but that doesn't mean it will continue to. Foreign stocks are beating the everloving fuck out of US stocks this year so for for example.
that's why he said global ETF

honestly abusing correlation seems only worth it if the assets have an equal return to stocks, all this junk has such low return even if its negatively correlated you're not going to get a free reduction in variance with it without killing your return. That's why i heard some paper showed its optimal to just go 100% stocks. Even if your a boomer, bonds aren't really worth it, you can just adjust your spending if theres a downturn and still come out ahead.

Trying to finds stocks/etfs that are weakly correlated seems to be the play.

61872998
>>61872888
There are a lot of assets that meet or beat equity markets with CAGR and are low correlation. Some are right in the data here >>61872698

Gold for example has a higher average annual return, better risk adjusted return, and a 0.1 correlation.

61873012
>>61872467
All on btc shorts. Outperform those gay indexes for the next three years in one week

61873080
>>61872467
Why do you focus on yield so much instead of total returns?

It's a lot of US large cap equity exposure with tax inefficiency if it's in a taxable account. You'll get big dividend though.

I like PTY, ASGI, etc for yield personally.

61873145
>>61872998
no it fucking doesn't, in the last 110 years it has returned 5% while the stock market returned 10%

61873184
>>61873145
ik this is probably bait but that's a very silly time period to look at because before we got off the gold standard it was fixed ounces/USD.

Meaning 0% growth for half that period dragging the CAGR way down lol. Doesn't make sense to look at the return pre Nixon shock for that reason.

61873190
>>61872433
if you like uncorrelated risk adjusted-returns you should look at alternative investments.

61873207
>>61873190
Returns are totally dependent on the managers imho, it's a cool class. I'm not a huge fan of the illiquidity personally.

I do like some of them them, especially private farmland/timberland.

Not a huge fan of venture or growth PE, guess I'm lame.

61873214
>>61873207
have you looked into managed futures?

61873220
>>61873080
I use my brokerage as my main savings account. Instead of getting $500/month in a high yield savings account I rather get $1400, 50-75% I could reinvest. But since you do this for a living I'm going to listen and allocate more money for growth rather than yield going forward, and you're right about the taxes, I didn't think too much about that. Thanks!

61873222
>>61873214
I cant believe I forgot about those!

I use the ETFs for simplicity. ISMF/CTA for crisis alpha. I almost went DBMF too, but I prefer the purer systematic trend heavy ones.

Do you have any strong opinions on them?

Seems like extreme negative correlation, like -0.4 with 6-8% CAGR which is completely acceptable if you're rebalancing with a really aggressive equity portfolio. I considered pairing them with TQQQ or SOXL to be a total jackass at once point and pussed out,

61873231
>>61873220
You accept more risk (volatility) for those higher returns, that's the tradeoff. If you are OK with higher risk then you could always choose one of those balanced allocation funds.

AOR for example just rebalances a 60% stock / 40% bond index portfolio.

AOA does the same thing but 80% stock (more risk)

These really are the easy button for people that don't want to self-manage imo.

Probably a good idea to put the portion that's your emergency fund into something boring and very lowvol but decent yield. Check out JPST, that might be a good fit.

61873256
>>61873222
>>61873190
those are the returns for my managed futures program, im a CTA. its great uncorrelated returns but theres a lot of programs that under perform or blow up (-60%+ years). its definitely more liquid than other alternatives.

61873270
>>61873256
Damn dude you're crushing it. What's the time period on those returns?

Mind if I ask what your strategy is?

Any specific managed futures ETFs you like? Are they even close to replicating the actuals?

61873283
>>61873270
thats 20 months of performance trading 8 different futures markets. semi-systematic medium frequency trend following. im not too familiar with the ETFs that track managed futures but they usually focus on the billion dollar CTAs and those programs are lower returns lower risk just trying to be uncorrelated.

61873448
>>61873184
ok, its still not beating the stock market unlike your claim, and if you take the last 3 years out and it drops a lot. That is insane volatility that it doesn't converge after 50 years. Realistically the actual return is maybe 7% and you get very long periods of dogshit ~3%, and for all that volatility it still doesn't match the market.

61873450
I’m currently halfway through finishing my CFP course
Any advice for someone trying to hit the ground running, beyond spamming LinkedIn? Or should I just accept that this job market is going to rape me until I give up hope

61873477
>>61872433
Cant ai just do most of that?

61873686
>>61873477
This. Almost tooka financial advisor job. Then I realized, "why the fuck would anybody talk to a human about this?"

61873827
>>61873686
Cause the AI will tell you something plausible that it thinks you want to hear, and it will partially or mostly hallucinate the data it uses to deliver that response

61873887
>>61872433
Do you hold any bitcoin? What are your thoughts on it and does your firm/company advise on it?

61874040
>>61872561
I am a europoor(in a very poor country) so I dont think i have access to most the stuff you are listing. I can only buy ETFs, I have most my portfolio in a Global market cap ETF some in europe ETF and a little in small cap value international and emerging markets. Also bought a sizable stack of silver sub 30 dollars but its going to be a bitch to sell. I dont invest in bonds since I think that every government will just keep on printing.

61874046
>>61873450
Connections are everything, and the exam will be easier than you think. The classes were hugely valuable, were harder and more useful than my master's degree courses. Most companies will have you try to peddle shit insurance products to friends/family at the entry level it's gross.

>>61873477
>>61873686
Maybe someday, not right now. For what >>61873827 said and because it just sucks at answering niche or complex questions. When I ask it things it usually feeds me flat out wrong answers that would be passable to someone that didn't do any research.

One example is having it try to pick stocks. Gets obliterated by the index funds every time. It's a consistent loser at this because it can't make forward projections and the question is too complicated for it. Tax questions are a horror show too, you'd think it would be good at those.

The main issue with AI in my eyes is that it just doesn't understand humans/human nature. Most of my job is behavioral.

>>61873887
I do, I made a bunch of money in it 2016ish and now build and rebalance a position in my retirement accounts (5-10% allocation).

61874061
>>61874040
Wish I knew more about EU investing, I'm completely specialized for US investing so it's out of my wheelhouse. I only have a handful of expat/foreign clients.

EU bonds have been zero or even negative for a long time. I won't touch them because they don't compensate you for loaning them money, and I can't believe people keep buying them.

Apparently it has something to do with their SIPC insurance equivalent, safer park for cash than a checking account basically because of the federal coverage you get by buying a bond. I haven't looked much into it just what I heard.

61874087
>>61873887
>does your firm/company advise on it?

Forgot to answer this part. We don't buy it in our portfolios, but we do help clients manage the risk associated with it. Some people are believers in crypto so we highlight the risks (volatility, no intrinsic value, etc) and then work with them to figure out how much of their overall investments is a prudent amount to put into that risk asset. I personally cap myself at 10% for both gold and crypto.

Crypto is actually considered speculation instead of investing by most managers. Kind of like commodities/gold/NFTs.

61874261
>>61873448
>its still not beating the stock market
It does in the 26-year backward looking period in the data array from the picture by 30bp. Instead of just pulling 7% out of your booty you could spend 10 seconds doing the present value calculation if you really wanted.


It's about 9.8% annualized if you go all the way back to '71 from now ($39-$5,000). That's definitely nothing to scoff at when constructing a portfolio and hedging equity markets considering the 0.1 correlation.

>That is insane volatility
Volatility is good in a portfolio of non-correlated assets that's rebalanced outside of tolerance bands.

>all that volatility it still doesn't match the market
Almost keeps up with it and doesn't move in the same direction, which is the idea. Non-correlated assets, rebalancing the volatility, and risk-return tradeoff are portfolio construction 101.

61874286
Alright anon, I'm out. Have a great day and I hope every one of you gets to retire early.

PS long nursing homes

61874295
>>61872433
Is there a gap in the asset management & financial planning software market? Seems you are just using an excel sheet there. Is there any way your life could be easier or more automated?

I'm a developer and I like money

61874345
>>61874295
The software is pretty comprehensive and generally way deeper than just an excel sheet, but of course there's an industry spectrum of how deep/detailed the analysis goes by firm and by program.

Some is straight up basically a cash flows projection laid on top of a balance sheet (excel). The people that use this are shitty whole life insurance people.

It's the auxiliary software where the money is at right now it seems. AI that reads trusts using OCR and spits out a summary to help you find issues. Tax software. Stuff like that.

Our software for portfolio management (have used 3) is AWFUL though. That's a big gap for asset management imho.
